panels.description: The checkpoints mark the last block a stage can recover from in the case of a crash or shutdown of the node

panels.description: The throughput of the Engine API newPayload method. The metric is the amount of gas processed in a block, divided by the time it took to process the newPayload request.

panels.description:
The throughput of the node's executor. The metric is the amount of gas processed in a block, divided by the time it took to process the block.

Note: For mainnet, the block range 2,383,397-2,620,384 will be slow because of the 2016 DoS attack.
panels.title: Execution throughput

panels.description: Engine API messages received by the CL, either engine_newPayload or engine_forkchoiceUpdated

panels.description: Counts the number of failed response deliveries due to client request termination.
panels.title: Failed Engine API Response Deliveries

panels.description: Latency histograms for the engine_getPayloadBodiesByHashV1 and engine_getPayloadBodiesByRangeV1 RPC APIs
panels.title: Engine API getPayloadBodies Latency

panels.description: Total pipeline runs triggered by the sync controller
panels.title: Pipeline runs

panels.description: The time it takes for operations that are part of block validation, but not execution or state root, to complete.
panels.title: Block validation overhead

panels.description: Time from starting to spawn proof workers until each worker marks itself as available (after initialization, before processing first job). Measures worker initialization overhead.
panels.title: Proof Worker Spawn-to-Available Duration

panels.description: Time spent creating database provider in proof workers. High values indicate database connection pool contention or slow transaction creation.
panels.title: Worker DB Provider Creation Duration

panels.description: Time spent creating ProofTaskTx structure in proof workers. Measures overhead of setting up proof computation context.
panels.title: Worker ProofTaskTx Creation Duration

panels.description: The max metrics (Max storage workers and Max account workers) are displayed as dotted lines to highlight the configured upper limits.
panels.title: Active MultiProof Workers

panels.description:
**Total Duration**: Complete time to create an overlay state provider with reverts.

This includes:
- Base provider creation (DB connection)
- Block hash lookup (if block_hash is set)
- Reverts validation (checking changeset availability)
- Trie reverts fetch (if needed)
- State reverts fetch (if needed)

**When to investigate**: Values >500ms indicate performance issues. Check child panels to identify bottleneck.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Total Duration

panels.description:
**Provider Creation**: Time to acquire a read-only database provider from the connection pool.

**Normal range**: <10ms
**High values (>50ms)**: Database connection pool contention or slow DB init.

**Action**: If consistently high, increase DB connection pool size or investigate DB performance.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Provider Creation

panels.description:
**Block Hash Lookup**: Time to convert block hash to block number for revert collection.

**Only measured when**: block_hash is set (not None)
**Normal range**: <10ms
**High values (>50ms)**: Slow BlockHashNumbers table lookups or missing index.

**Action**: Check DB index health on BlockHashNumbers table.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Block Hash Lookup

panels.description:
**Reverts Validation**: Time to check if MerkleChangeSets data is available for the requested block range.

**What it does**:
- Checks MerkleChangeSets stage checkpoint (upper bound)
- Checks MerkleChangeSets prune checkpoint (lower bound)
- Validates requested block is within available range
- Determines if reverts are needed (checkpoint == requested block)

**Normal range**: <10ms
**High values (>50ms)**: Slow checkpoint table reads.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Reverts Validation

panels.description:
**Trie Reverts Fetch**: Time to fetch trie structure changes from MerkleChangeSets table.

**Only executed when**: reverts_required is true (requested block != checkpoint)
**Normal range**: <100ms for few blocks, <500ms for many blocks
**High values (>500ms)**: Large changeset range or slow DB I/O

**What affects duration**:
- Checkpoint delta (blocks behind): Higher = more data to fetch
- Block activity: More trie changes = longer fetch

**Optimization**: If 'Checkpoint Delta' shows high values, investigate why checkpoint is lagging.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Trie Reverts Fetch

panels.description:
**State Reverts (from_reverts)**: Time to materialize account/storage state changes via HashedPostState::from_reverts().

**Only executed when**: reverts_required is true (requested block != checkpoint)
**What it fetches**: Account changes + Storage changes from AccountChangeSets and StorageChangeSets tables
**Normal range**: <100ms
**High values (>100ms)**: Large number of state changes or slow DB I/O

**What affects duration**:
- Checkpoint delta: More blocks behind = more changes
- Transaction activity: High gas blocks = more state changes

**Note**: Usually faster than Trie Reverts because state changes are more localized.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - From Reverts

panels.description: Number of revert entries collected per invocation (0 when the revert path is skipped).
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Revert Entry Counts

panels.description:
**Reverts Decision Breakdown**: Shows which of 3 mutually exclusive code paths is being taken.

**1. block_hash not set (fast path)**: 
- block_hash parameter is None
- No reverts collected, uses overlays directly
- Fastest path, no DB queries

**2. reverts not required (optimization)**:
- block_hash is set BUT requested block == MerkleChangeSets checkpoint
- Optimization skip introduced in PR #19412
- Avoids fetching reverts when at DB tip

**3. reverts required (fetch path)**:
- block_hash is set AND requested block != checkpoint
- Expensive: fetches trie + state reverts
- Should be 0 in reth-bench!

**Investigation**: If 'reverts required' > 0 in reth-bench, check 'Checkpoint Delta' to see why checkpoint is lagging.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Reverts Decision Breakdown

panels.description:
**Fetch Efficiency**: Tracks whether revert fetches return data or are empty (wasted queries).

**Metrics tracked**:
- **trie reverts empty (wasted)**: Fetched trie reverts but got 0 results
- **trie reverts non-empty (legitimate)**: Fetched trie reverts and got data
- **state reverts empty (wasted)**: Fetched state reverts but got 0 results  
- **state reverts non-empty (legitimate)**: Fetched state reverts and got data

**Ideal**: 0 empty fetches (all fetches return data)
**Problem**: High empty rates mean wasting 100-500ms on queries that return nothing

**Root cause of empty fetches**: Requesting reverts for blocks with no trie/state changes (rare on mainnet)

**Action**: If consistently high empty rates, consider skipping fetch entirely for those cases.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Fetch Efficiency (Empty vs Non-Empty)

panels.description:
**Checkpoint Delta**: Distance (in blocks) between requested block and MerkleChangeSets checkpoint.

**Calculation**: checkpoint_delta = upper_bound (checkpoint) - requested_block

**Only recorded when**: reverts_required is true (reverts are being fetched)

**Interpretation**:
- **Delta = 0**: Impossible (would trigger optimization skip)
- **Delta = 1-10 blocks**: Slight lag, acceptable
- **Delta > 10 blocks**: Checkpoint significantly behind, investigate!
- **Delta > 100 blocks**: Major issue with checkpoint updates

**Why it matters**: Higher delta = more changeset data to fetch = slower Trie/State Reverts

**Root causes of high delta**:
1. MerkleChangeSets stage not running/slow
2. Backfilling not keeping up with chain tip
3. Database write bottleneck

**Action**: If consistently >0 in reth-bench, this explains unexpected reverts. Check why checkpoint isn't advancing.
panels.title: Overlay State Provider - Checkpoint Delta

panels.description: Histogram for state root latency, the time spent blocked waiting for the state root.
panels.title: State root latency

panels.description:
**Beacon Executed Blocks**: Tracks the rate of blocks executed from the consensus layer (CL) via Engine API.

**What this measures**: Blocks processed through newPayload/forkchoiceUpdated calls from the beacon node.

**Expected values**:
- **Normal operation**: ~0.083 blocks/sec (5 blocks/minute on 12s block time)
- **During sync**: 0 blocks/sec (uses pipeline instead)
- **During reorg**: May spike temporarily

**Problem indicators**:
- **Consistently 0**: Not receiving blocks from CL, check beacon node connection
- **Very high**: Potential reorg or CL sending duplicates
panels.title: Consensus Engine - Total Beacon Executed Blocks

panels.description: Time to execute MerkleChangeSets stage. High values indicate stage is slow.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - Execution Duration

panels.description: Number of blocks processed per stage execution. High values mean infrequent updates causing checkpoint lag.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - Blocks Per Execution

panels.description: Total number of state revert items (accounts + storage slots) collected per execution. Shows workload size.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - State Reverts Collected

panels.description: Total number of trie revert items (account nodes + storage nodes) collected per execution. Shows trie workload size.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - Trie Reverts Collected

panels.description: Average state revert items per block. Shows if workload scales linearly with block count.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - State Reverts Per Block

panels.description: Average trie revert items per block. Shows if trie workload scales linearly with block count.
panels.title: MerkleChangeSets - Trie Reverts Per Block

panels.description: How much time is spent in the multiproof task

panels.description: The average commit time for database transactions. Generally, this should not be a limiting factor in syncing.
panels.title: Average commit time

panels.description: The size of the database over time
panels.title: Database growth

panels.description:
The type of the pages in the database:

- **Leaf** pages contain KV pairs.
- **Branch** pages contain information about keys in the leaf pages
- **Overflow** pages store large values and should generally be avoided if possible
panels.title: Database pages

panels.description: The maximum time the database transaction was open.
panels.title: Max transaction open time

panels.description: The average time a database transaction was open.
panels.title: Average transaction open time

panels.description: The number of pages on the MDBX freelist
panels.title: Freelist

panels.description: The maximum time the static files operation which commits a writer took.
panels.title: Max writer commit time

panels.description: The size of segments in the static files
panels.title: Segments size

panels.description: The size of the static files over time
panels.title: Static Files growth

panels.description: The block number of the tip of the canonical chain from the blockchain tree.

panels.description: Total number of blocks in the tree's block buffer
panels.title: Block buffer blocks

panels.description: Internal errors in the header downloader. These are expected to happen from time to time.

panels.title: Requests

panels.description: The number of blocks and size in bytes of those blocks

panels.title: I/O

panels.description: Internal errors in the bodies downloader. These are expected to happen from time to time.

panels.description: The number of connected peers and in-progress requests for bodies.
panels.title: Requests

panels.title: Failed Jobs

targets.description: Archive and full nodes prune headers, transactions and receipts in MDBX (hot db) after they have been written to static files (cold db). Full nodes additionally prune history indices.

panels.description: Tracks the number of regular tasks currently ran by the executor.
panels.title: Task Executor regular tasks

panels.description: 100% = 1 core
panels.title: CPU
